sourceDesc.p: This publication constitutes a remediation of the printed Inns of Court collection. Information on original sources for transcriptions can be accessed via the Document Descriptions.
For a full list of REED collections, editors, executive board members, and staff, please visit http://reed.utoronto.ca/people

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the taxon prefix are pointers to entities in the taxonomy.xml file. For example, taxon:church dereferences to taxonomy.xml#church.
Private URIs using the gloss prefix are pointers to entities in the glossary.xml file. For example, gloss:histrio-1 dereferences to glossary.xml#histrio-1.

projectDesc.p: Records of Early English Drama (REED) is an international scholarly project that is establishing for the first time the context from which the drama of Shakespeare and his contemporaries grew. Founded in 1976, REED has worked since then to locate, transcribe, and edit historical documents containing evidence of drama, secular music, and other communal entertainment and ceremony from the Middle Ages until 1642, when the Puritans closed the London theatres.

div.head: f 112v(4 May)
div.ab: fforasmuche it is found by experience That the vtterbarresters, of this howse, as alsoe other gentlemen vnder the barre doe vsually vnder hand & secretlie contrarie to the Statutes & orders of this howse, make sale of theire Chambers, for great sommes of money, and convert the same to theire owne privat vse to the great preiudice and state of this howse And for that contrariewise It is seen from the experience of other howses of Courte, that throughe sale made of Chambers by the governors of such howse muche benefitt and proffitte hath growne to the general state of the same: with furderance and due content of the Studentes there, And forasmuche as this howse att this present is muche indebted by reason of the late showe and sportes made by the gentlemen of this howse before his highnes att whitehall Amountinge in Charges vnto the howse (over and besides the stocke of this howse,) not soe litle as xijC li. which requires somme extraordynarie and unwonted course of supply, but noe meanes as yetfor no meanes are as yet discerned therein soe fittinge as suche husbandlye course of admittances, Be it therefore enacted att this present ^parliament that hencefourth all admittances into anye Chamber or Chambers of this howse in possession or Revercion (other then Benchers Chambers priviledged by acte of parliament) shalbe made from tyme to tyme by acte of parliament, and not by the Threasourer of this ^howse allone as heretofore haue ben, and that all admittances otherwise had or made shalbe voyde, And it is furder enacted that vppon everye suche admittance by acte of parliament the partie or parties to be admitted shall over and above the former vsuall & accustomed fine for an admittance paye vnto the Threasourer of this howse suche furder somme or sommes of money for such Chamber or Chambers as shalbe then assessed and sett downe for suche admittances as the worth of the chamber or chambers will in the iudgement of such parliament afford to be sold betweene partie and partie, Nevertheles it is alsoe furder enacted that everye person soe admitted and payinge suche somme of money shall att any tyme after vppon his surrender of suche his interest in suche Chamber or Chambers, wherein he shall stand soe admitted as aforesaid, haue repaide backe vnto him by the Threasourer of this howse three full partes in foure partes devided of the wholl fine or somme of money which he shall haue soe formerlie paid and disbursed as aforesaid, And this acte to be sufficient warrant and discharge to suche Threasourer for the tyme beinge in that behaulf,: Provided alwayes that this acte or anie thinge therein contayned shall not extend to anye Chamber, Chambers, or Rowmes, wherein anye of this Socyetie haue anie graunt by anye acte of parliament, but that everye suche person and persons theire executors and assignes shall haue Contynue and enioye there said Chambers and Romes, whereof and wherein they stand soe admitted with all priviledges and benefittes in as lardge and beneficiall manner to all purposes as the same were graunted vnto them or to anie other vnder whome they Clayme the same by force of anye acte of parliament heretofore made anye thinge in this acte to the contrarie notwithstandinge/

note.ab: The phrase ‘late showe and sportes’ (p 151, l.41) refers to Beaumont’s Masque of the Inner Temple and Gray’s Inn, performed in the Banqueting House, Whitehall, on 20 February 1612/13, following the marriage of Princess Elizabeth and the count palatine. The figure ‘xijC li.’(£1200), if doubled to allow for Gray’s Inn’s share, tallies roughly with the total of £2255 8s 11d calculated by Orbison (ed), Collections 12, p 7, to have been the cost of George Chapman’s masque presented by the Middle Temple and Lincoln’s Inn for the same occasion.

div.head: f 120(10 July)
div.ab: At this Parliament yt is ordered that Mr Lumley the draper shallbe paid fower powndes twelve shillinges & sixe pence, for scarlett ymployed for the Marshall at the Maske
